God of the torch, whose soul-illuming flame</br>Beams brightest radiance o'er the human heart;</br>Of every woe the cure,</br>Of every joy the source;
To thee I sing:  if haply may the muse</br>Pour forth the song unblam'd from these dull haunts,</br>Where never beams thy torch</br>To cheer the sullen scene;
From these dull haunts, where monkish science holds,</br>In sullen gloom her solitary reign;</br>And spurns the reign of love,</br>And spurns thy genial sway.
God of the ruddy cheek and beaming eye,</br>Whose soft sweet gaze thrills thro' the bounding heart,</br>With no unholy joy</br>I pour the lay to thee.
I pour the lay to thee, though haply doom'd</br>In solitary woe to waste my years;</br>Though doom'd perchance to die</br>Unlov'd and unbewail'd.
Yet will the lark, in iron cage inthrall'd,</br>Chaunt forth her hymn to greet the morning sun,</br>As wide his brilliant beam</br>Illumes the landskip round;
As distant 'mid the woodland haunts is heard</br>The feather'd quire, she chaunts her prison'd hymn,</br>And hails the beam of joy,</br>Of joy to her denied.
Friend to each noblest feeling of the soul,</br>To thee I hymn, for every joy is thine;</br>And every virtue comes</br>To join thy generous train.
Lur'd by the splendour of thy beamy torch,</br>Beacon of bliss, young love expands his plumes,</br>And leads his willing slaves</br>To wear thy flowery bands;
And then he yields the follies of his reign,</br>Throws down the torch that scorches up the soul,</br>And lights the purer flame</br>That glows serene with thee.
And chasten'd Friendship comes, whose mildest sway</br>Shall cheer the hour of age, when fainter beam</br>The fading flame of love,</br>The fading flame of life.
Parent of every bliss!  the busy soul</br>Of Fancy oft will paint, in brightest hues,</br>How calm, how clear, thy torch</br>Illumes the wintry hour;
Will paint the wearied labourer, at that hour</br>When friendly darkness yields a pause to toil,</br>Returning blithely home</br>To each domestic joy;
Will paint the well-trimm'd fire, the frugal meal</br>Prepar'd by fond solicitude to please,</br>The ruddy children round</br>That climb the father's knee:
And oft will Fancy rise above the lot</br>Of honest poverty, oft paint the state</br>Where happiest man is blest</br>With mediocrity;
When toil, no longer irksome and constrain'd</br>By hard necessity, but comes to please,</br>To vary the still hour</br>Of tranquil happiness.
Why, Fancy, wilt thou, o'er the lovely scene</br>Pouring thy vivid hues, why, sorceress sweet!</br>Soothe sad reality</br>With visionary bliss?
Ah!  rather gaze where science' hallow'd light</br>Resplendent shines:  ah!  rather lead thy son</br>Through all her mystic paths</br>To drink the sacred spring.
Let calm philosophy supply the void,</br>And fill the vacant heart; lead calmly on</br>Along the unvaried path,</br>To age's drear abode;
And teach how dreadful death to happiness,</br>What thousand horrors wait the last adieu,</br>When every tie is broke,</br>And every charm dissolv'd.
Then only dreadful; friendly to the wretch</br>Who wanes in solitary listlessness,</br>Nor knows the joys of life,</br>Nor knows the dread of death.</br>
